title: 107_hr1526
content: The "Agriculture Competition Enhancement Act of 2001" prohibits acquisitions of voting securities or assets in the livestock, poultry, or agricultural commodity business that exceed $1,000,000,000 and would reduce competition, affecting prices paid to producers. The "Agriculture Competition Enhancement Act of 2001" prohibits acquisitions exceeding $1,000,000,000 in the livestock, poultry, or agricultural commodity business that would reduce competition and impact prices paid to producers. The Act requires individuals filing notifications under the Clayton Act to also notify the Secretary, who will publish the notice, accept public comments, and review the proposed acquisition within 30 days. The Agriculture Competition Enhancement Act of 2001 requires the Secretary to review acquisitions over $1 billion in the livestock, poultry, or agricultural commodity industry. The review aims to assess potential impacts on producer prices, market power, and anticompetitive behavior. The Secretary must prepare a detailed report with findings and economic analysis to determine if the acquisition may harm competition or lead to a monopoly. The report is then sent to the Office of Special Counsel. The Secretary must conduct an economic analysis to determine if an acquisition over $1 billion in the livestock, poultry, or agricultural commodity industry may harm competition or create a monopoly. The report with findings is sent to the Office of Special Counsel and published in the Federal Register. SEC. 4. ENFORCEMENT PROVISIONS: Clayton Act sections apply to section 2 violations. SEC. 5. SPECIAL COUNSEL FOR AGRICULTURE: Office established for agricultural antitrust issues. SEC. 6. GAO STUDY: Conducted for further analysis. The Comptroller General will conduct a study on the Grain Inspection, Packers and Stockyard Administration's need for additional resources to monitor the meat packing industry and disparities in administrative authority. A report will be submitted to Congress within 1 year. SEC. 7. DEFINITIONS. This section defines key terms used in the Act, such as "antitrust laws," "basic agricultural commodity," "livestock," "person," "poultry," and "Secretary."
